revision.text:
{{italic title}} {{Refimprove|date=September 2010}} '''''The Thirty-Six Dramatic Situations''''' is a descriptive list which was created by [[Georges Polti]] to categorize every dramatic situation that might occur in a story or performance. To do this Polti analyzed classical [[ancient Greece|Greek]] texts, plus classical and contemporaneous French works. He also analyzed a handful of non-French authors. In his introduction, Polti claims to be continuing the work of [[Carlo Gozzi]], who also identified 36 situations.
==Publication history== {{quote box|align=right|width=300px|quote=“Gozzi maintained that there can be but thirty-six tragic situations. Schiller took great pains to find more, but he was unable to find even so many as Gozzi.” |source= —[[Johann Wolfgang von Goethe|Goethe]]<ref>{{cite book |last=Polti |first=Georges |authorlink=Georges Polti |title=The Thirty-Six Dramatic Situations |url=http://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Index:The_thirty-six_dramatic_situations_(1921).djvu |year=1921 |month= |origyear=1916 |publisher=James Knapp Reeve |location=Franklin, Ohio |page=3}}</ref>}} This list was published in a book of the same name, which contains extended explanations and examples. The original French-language book was written in the 19th century. An English translation was published in 1916 and continues to be reprinted to this day.
The list is popularized as an aid for writers, but it is also used by dramatists, [[storytelling|storyteller]]s and many others. Other similar lists have since been made.
== The 36 situations == Each situation is stated, then followed by the necessary elements for each situation and a brief description.
# '''[[Supplication]]''' #* a persecutor; a [[wikt:suppliant|suppliant]]; a power in authority, whose decision is doubtful. #* The suppliant appeals to the power in authority for deliverance from the persecutor. # '''Deliverance''' #* an unfortunate; a threatener; a rescuer #* The unfortunate has caused a conflict, and the threatener is to carry out justice, but the rescuer saves the unfortunate. ''Examples: [[Iphigenia in Tauris|Ifigenia in Tauride]], [[Deliverance]]'' # '''Crime pursued by vengeance''' #* a criminal; an avenger #* The criminal commits a crime that will not see justice, so the avenger seeks justice by punishing the criminal. ''Example: [[The Count of Monte Cristo]]'' # '''Vengeance taken for kin upon kin''' #* Guilty Kinsman; an Avenging Kinsman; remembrance of the Victim, a relative of both. #* Two entities, the Guilty and the Avenging Kinsmen, are put into conflict over wrongdoing to the Victim, who is allied to both. ''Example: [[Hamlet]]'' # '''Pursuit''' #* punishment; a fugitive #* the fugitive flees punishment for a misunderstood conflict. ''Example: [[Les Misérables]]'' # '''Disaster''' #* a vanquished power; a victorious enemy ''or'' a [[message|messenger]] #* The vanquished power falls from their place after being defeated by the victorious enemy or being informed of such a defeat by the messenger. ''Example: [[Agamemnon (play)]]'' # '''Falling prey to cruelty/misfortune''' #* an unfortunate; a master ''or'' a misfortune #* The unfortunate suffers from misfortune and/or at the hands of the master. ''Example: [[Job (biblical figure)]]'' # '''Revolt''' #* a tyrant; a conspirator #* The tyrant, a cruel power, is plotted against by the conspirator. ''Example: [[Julius Caesar (play)]]'' # '''Daring enterprise''' #* a bold leader; an object; an adversary #* The bold leader takes the object from the adversary by overpowering the adversary. ''Example: [[Queste del Saint Graal]]'' # [[kidnapping|'''Abduction''']] #* an abductor; the abducted; a guardian #* The abductor takes the abducted from the guardian. ''Example: [[Helen of Troy]]'' # '''The enigma''' #* a problem; an interrogator; a seeker #* The interrogator poses a problem to the seeker and gives a seeker better ability to reach the seeker's goals. ''Example: [[Oedipus]] and the [[Sphinx]]'' # '''Obtaining''' #* (a [[Solicitor]] & an adversary who is refusing) ''or'' (an arbitrator & opposing parties) #* The solicitor is at odds with the adversary who refuses to give the solicitor an object in the possession of the adversary, or an arbitrator decides who gets the object desired by opposing parties (the solicitor and the adversary). ''Example: [[Apple of Discord]]'' # '''Enmity of kin''' #* a [[wikt:malevolent|Malevolent]] Kinsman; a [[Hate]]d ''or'' a reciprocally-hating Kinsman #* The Malevolent Kinsman and the Hated or a second Malevolent Kinsman conspire together. ''Example: [[As You Like It]]'' # '''Rivalry of kin''' #* the Preferred Kinsman; the [[wikt:rejection|Rejected]] Kinsman; the Object of Rivalry #* The Object of Rivalry chooses the Preferred Kinsman over the Rejected Kinsman. ''Example: [[Wuthering Heights]]'' # '''Murderous [[adultery]]''' #* two Adulterers; a Betrayed [[Marriage|Spouse]] #* Two Adulterers conspire to kill the Betrayed Spouse. ''Example: [[Clytemnestra]] and [[Aegisthus]]'' # [[Insanity|'''Madness''']] #* a Madman; a Victim #* The Madman goes insane and wrongs the Victim. # [[wiktionary:fatal|'''Fatal''']] '''imprudence''' #* the Imprudent; a Victim ''or'' an Object Lost #* The Imprudent, by neglect or ignorance, loses the Object Lost or wrongs the Victim. # [[Will (philosophy)|'''Involuntary''']]''' crimes of love''' #* a Lover; a Beloved; a [[wiktionary:reveal|Reveal]]er #* The Lover and the Beloved have unknowingly broken a taboo through their romantic relationship, and the Revealer reveals this to them Example: [[Oedipus]], [[Jocasta]] and the messenger from Corinth. # '''Slaying of kin unrecognized''' #* the Slayer; an Unrecognized Victim #* The Slayer kills the Unrecognized Victim. ''Example: [[Oedipus]] and Laius'' # '''Self-sacrifice for an ideal''' #* a [[Hero]]; an [[Ideal (ethics)|Ideal]]; a [[Creditor]] ''or'' a [[Person]]/[[Object (philosophy)|Thing]] sacrificed #* The Hero sacrifices the Person or Thing for their Ideal, which is then taken by the Creditor. # '''[[Self-sacrifice]] for kin''' #* a Hero; a Kinsman; a Creditor ''or'' a Person/Thing sacrificed #* The Hero sacrifices a Person or Thing for their Kinsman, which is then taken by the Creditor. # '''All sacrificed for [[Passion (emotion)|passion]]''' #* a Lover; an Object of fatal Passion; the Person/Thing sacrificed #* A Lover sacrifices a Person or Thing for the Object of their Passion, which is then lost forever. # '''Necessity of sacrificing loved ones''' #* a Hero; a Beloved Victim; the Necessity for the Sacrifice #* The Hero wrongs the Beloved Victim because of the Necessity for their Sacrifice. # '''Rivalry of superior vs. inferior''' #* a Superior Rival; an [[wikt:inferiority|Inferior]] Rival; the Object of Rivalry #* A Superior Rival bests an Inferior Rival and wins the Object of Rivalry. # '''[[Adultery]]''' #* two Adulterers; a [[Deceive]]d Spouse #* Two Adulterers conspire against the Deceived Spouse. # '''Crimes of love''' #* a Lover; the Beloved #* A Lover and the Beloved break a taboo by initiating a romantic relationship ''Example: Sigmund and his sister in [[The Valkyrie]]'' # '''Discovery of the [[dishonour]] of a loved one''' #* a Discoverer; the Guilty One #* The Discoverer discovers the wrongdoing committed by the Guilty One. # '''Obstacles to love''' #* two Lovers; an Obstacle #* Two Lovers face an Obstacle together. ''Example: [[Romeo and Juliet]]'' # '''An enemy loved''' #* a Lover; the Beloved Enemy; the [[Hate]]r #* The allied Lover and Hater have diametrically opposed attitudes towards the Beloved Enemy. # [[wiktionary:ambition|'''Ambition''']] #* an Ambitious Person; a Thing [[Covet]]ed; an Adversary #* The Ambitious Person seeks the Thing Coveted and is opposed by the Adversary. ''Example: [[Macbeth]]'' # [[Conflict (narrative)|'''Conflict''']]''' with a [[god]]''' #* a Mortal; an [[Immortality|Immortal]] #* The Mortal and the Immortal enter a conflict. # [[Error|'''Mistaken''']] '''jealousy''' #* a [[Jealous]] One; an Object of whose Possession He is Jealous; a Supposed Accomplice; a Cause ''or'' an Author of the Mistake #* The Jealous One falls victim to the Cause or the Author of the Mistake and becomes jealous of the Object and becomes conflicted with the Supposed Accomplice. # [[Error|'''Erroneous''']] '''judgment''' #* a Mistaken One; a Victim of the Mistake; a [[Cause]] ''or'' Author of the Mistake; the Guilty One #* The Mistaken One falls victim to the Cause or the Author of the Mistake and passes judgment against the Victim of the Mistake when it should be passed against the Guilty One instead. # '''[[Remorse]]''' #* a [[Culprit]]; a Victim ''or'' the Sin; an Interrogator #* The Culprit wrongs the Victim or commits the Sin, and is at odds with the Interrogator who seeks to understand the situation. # '''Recovery of a lost one''' #* a [[wikt:seeker|Seeker]]; the One Found #* The Seeker finds the One Found. # '''[[Grief|Loss]] of loved ones''' #* a Kinsman [[wikt:slay|Slain]]; a Kinsman Spectator; an [[Executioner]] #* The killing of the Kinsman Slain by the Executioner is witnessed by the Kinsman

The {{nihongo|'''United Nations University'''|国際連合大学|Kokusai rengō daigaku}} ('''UNU'''), established in 1973, is the academic and research arm of the [[United Nations]]. It is headquartered in [[Shibuya, Tokyo]], [[Japan]], with diplomatic status as a UN institution. Since 2010, UNU has been authorized by the [[United Nations General Assembly]] to grant degrees. It also provides a bridge between the UN and the international academic, policy-making and private sector communities.
==Organisation and leadership==
The university is headed by a rector, who holds the rank of [[Under-Secretary-General of the United Nations]].
To date, there have been six Rectors at UNU. The current Rector, since March 2013, is Dr. [[David M. Malone]] of Canada.
List of Rectors of United Nations University: {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! # !! Rector || Took office !! Left office |- | 1 || [[James M. Van Ginkel]] || 1 September 1997 || 1 September 2007 |- | 5 || [[Konrad Osterwalder]] || 1 September 2007 || 28 February 2013 |- | 6 || [[David M. Malone]] || 1 March 2013 || Incumbent |}
The Council of UNU<ref>{{cite web|url=http://unu.edu/administration/unu-council|title=UNU Council|work=unu.edu|access-date=29 May 2011|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110615160724/http://unu.edu/administration/unu-council|archive-date=15 June 2011|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref> is the governing board of the University and is composed of 24 members who are appointed by the [[Secretary-General of the United Nations]] with the concurrence of the [[Director-General]] of [[UNESCO]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.unesco.org/new/en/unesco/about-us/who-we-are/director-general/|title=Director-General of UNESCO, Irina Bokova {{!}} United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization|website=www.unesco.org|access-date=2016-09-21}} </ref>
==History==
The University was established in 1973 and formally began its activities in 1976 following the signature of the permanent headquarters agreement between the United Nations and Japan.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://treaties.un.org/Pages/showDetails.aspx?objid=0800000280102344|title=UNTC|work=un.org}}</ref> The creation of the United Nations University was set in motion by Secretary-General [[U Thant]] in 1969.<ref name="UN_ARES2573XXIV">{{UN document |docid=A-RES-2573(XXIV) |type=Resolution |body=General Assembly |session=24 |resolution_number=2573 |accessdate=2008-05-02|date=13 December 1969|title=International university}}</ref>
===UNU Institutes and Vice-Rectorate=== Over the years, several Institutes of UNU were created to help with the research initiatives of the United Nations. Most notably, in 2007, a vice-rectorate was established in Bonn (UNU-ViE), Germany, as a way of strengthening UNU's presence in Europe. UNU-ViE is dedicated to developing knowledge-based sustainable solutions for global problems and is, therefore, an active organizer of international science policy dialogues for sustainability.
===UNU as a degree-granting institution===
In December 2009, the [[UN General Assembly]] amended the UNU Charter to make it possible for UNU to "grant and confer master's degrees and doctorates, diplomas, certificates and other academic distinctions under conditions laid down for that purpose in the statutes by the Council."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://unu.edu/about/charter#ART-1|title=UNU Charter|work=unu.edu}}</ref>
In 2013, UNU-ISP announced its intention to seek accreditation from the National Institution for Academic Degrees and University Evaluation (NIAD-UE) which is the Japanese accreditation agency for higher education institutions.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://isp.unu.edu/about/jobs/2013/programme_administrative_consultant.html|title=Jobs {{!}} UNU Institute for Sustainability and Peace|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=|accessdate=14 September 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130922084737/http://isp.unu.edu/about/jobs/2013/programme_administrative_consultant.html|archivedate=22 September 2013}}</ref> UNU-IAS was formally accredited in April 2015, making it the first international organization to be recognized by the NIAD-UE.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://unu.edu/news/news/unu-ias-accredited-by-the-national-institution-for-academic-degrees-and-university-evaluation-japan.html|title=UNU-IAS Accredited by the National Institution for Academic Degrees and University Evaluation|last=|first=|date=May 1, 2015|website=unu.edu|language=en-US|access-date=2017-04-03}}</ref>
==Locations== The university has several campuses spread over five continents. Its headquarters are located at the UNU Centre in Tokyo, Japan.

==Research ==
The role of the UN University is to generate new knowledge, educate, enhance individual and institutional capacities, and disseminate its useful information to relevant audiences. Within the scope of these five thematic clusters, the UN University undertakes:
*Cross-cultural, interdisciplinary research (utilizing innovative, science-based techniques and methodologies to study important global processes and elaborate forward-looking solutions) and targeted foresight and policy studies (aimed at developing policy-relevant prescriptions and evaluating the feasibility and comparative advantages of each option); *Postgraduate-level education (degree-oriented programmes and specialized training focused on problems and solutions rather than academic disciplines) and capacity development activities (aimed at helping developing and transitional countries to enhance local potential to address current problems/confront emergent challenges); and *Knowledge sharing and transfer (to deliver relevant information about UN University research, current scientific advances and best practices, in a timely manner and in a usable form, to those who most need it and can best utilize it).
As prescribed in the United Nations University Strategic Plan 2011–2014, the 26 major topics of focus of the UN University's academic work fall within five interdependent thematic clusters: #Peace, Security and Human Rights; Peace building and peace keeping, Conflict resolution and human security, Fostering dialogue among civilizations, religions and cultures, Human rights and ethics, Gender equality and mainstreaming, #Human and Socio-economic Development and Good Governance; Growth and economic development, Alleviating poverty and inequalities, Good governance, Enhancing educational capacities, Fair trade, Processes and consequences of regional integration and cooperation, Leadership, management and entrepreneurship. #Global Health, Population and Sustainable Livelihoods; Global health, Safe water and sanitation, Food and nutrition for human and social development, Combating HIV/AIDS, Population changes and migration. #Global Change and Sustainable Development; Climate change — adaptation and mitigation, Ecological health and biodiversity, New risk and vulnerabilities, Sustainable land, agriculture and natural resources management, Green economy. #Science, Technology, Innovation and Society; Science, technology and innovation, Sustainable energy futures, Sustainable urban futures, Sustainable housing and construction.
Collectively, these thematic clusters define the programme space within which the UN University undertakes its academic activities. Some key perspectives (such as gender equality, human rights and sustainability) pervade all aspects of the UN University's work.
==Institutes and programmes == The academic work of the United Nations University is carried out by a global system of Institutes, Operating Units, and Programmes located in more than 12 countries around the world.

revision.text:
{{Infobox school | name = Vernon Malone College and Career Academy | image = Vernon Malone College.png | motto = "Graduating students on time, college and career ready." | city = [[Raleigh, North Carolina|Raleigh]] | state = [[North Carolina]] | country = USA | schooltype = [[Public school (government funded)|Public]], [[Magnet school|magnet]], [[secondary education|secondary]] | founded = 2014 | sister_school = [[Southeast Raleigh Magnet High School]] | principal = Abby Stosenberg | key_people = [[Vernon Malone]] | grades = 9-12 | enrollment = 306 (2015-16)<ref>{{cite web|url=https://nces.ed.gov/ccd/schoolsearch/school_detail.asp?Search=1&DistrictID=3704720&SchoolPageNum=11&ID=370472003345|title=Vernon Malone College and Career Academy|publisher=National Center for Education Statistics|accessdate=November 26, 2018}}</ref> | schedule_type = Standard, 2 Core 2 Electives block | colors = Red, Black, Silver {{color box|#df2700}} {{color box|#000000}} {{color box|#c0c0c0}} | mascot = Silverhawk | website = {{URL|wcpss.net/vernonmalonecca}} }} '''Vernon Malone College and Career Academy''' (VMCCA)''',''' is one of the flagship schools of [[Wake County Public School System]]. It is an [[College application|application-based]] [[Early college high school|early college]] in [[Raleigh, North Carolina]], [[United States]]. The building was formerly a [[Coca-Cola]] [[Bottling company|bottling plant]] before being renovated to its current configuration.:<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.wcpss.net/domain/1254|title=About Us / About VMCCA|website=www.wcpss.net|language=en|access-date=2018-10-11}}</ref> It was first opened in 2014 as a [[Vocational education|career and technical education]] institution focusing on college and career readiness.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.ls3p.com/portfolio-item/vernonmalone/|title=Vernon Malone College and Career Academy - LS3P ASSOCIATES LTD|work=LS3P ASSOCIATES LTD|access-date=2018-10-11|language=en-US}}</ref> It has seven programs offered to students through [[Wake Technical Community College]] which include; [[Pharmaceutical technology|Biopharmaceutical Technology]], [[Automotive repair|Collision Repair]], [[Cosmetology]], [[Maintenance (technical)|Multi-Trades/Facilities Technology]], [[Nurse aide|Nurse Aide]], [[Video game development|Simulation and Game Development]], and [[Welding]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.wcpss.net/domain/2301|title=Wake Tech Programs / Overview|website=www.wcpss.net|language=en|access-date=2018-10-11}}</ref> The school is formally a part of the [[Wake County Public School System]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://drive.google.com/file/d/1AZSkB-1RMuhxeP_--98VbA9zD1FJYHdf/view|title=2018-19 High School PPG REVISED FINAL 2-16-18 V3.pdf|work=Google Docs|access-date=2018-10-11}}</ref> Their official mascot is a ''Silverhawk''.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://webarchive.wcpss.net/school-directory/high.html|title=WCPSS: High Schools|website=webarchive.wcpss.net|access-date=2018-10-11}}</ref>
== History == Vernon Malone College and Career Academy is named after former educator, politician, and school administrator, [[Vernon Malone]].<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=https://www.newsobserver.com/news/local/education/wake-ed-blog/article10284485.html|title=Wake County names new high school after Vernon Malone|work=newsobserver|access-date=2018-10-11|language=en}}</ref> Malone was consequential in merging Wake County Public Schools and Raleigh schools, ending [[racial segregation]] in the area.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.newsobserver.com/news/article200805494.html|title=Leader in merger of Wake County and Raleigh schools, Roy Tilley, dies|work=newsobserver|access-date=2018-10-11|language=en}}</ref> When choosing the name for the college and career academy, the Wake County [[board of education]] unanimously passed a resolution signifying their support for the school to be named after Malone, who had formerly served as the first Chairman for Wake County Public Schools following the merger.<ref name=":0" />
The inaugural principal when the school opened in 2014, was Dr. Ashlie Thompson.<ref name=":1">{{Cite news|url=https://www.newsobserver.com/news/local/education/article10067285.html|title=New Wake County technical high school short on students|work=newsobserver|access-date=2018-10-11|language=en}}</ref><ref name=":2">{{Cite web|url=https://www.wcpss.net/Page/266|title=Superintendent / Area Superintendents|website=www.wcpss.net|language=en|access-date=2018-10-11}}</ref> She has since left the position and now serves as an Area Superintendent for Wake County Public Schools in the district that Vernon Malone College and Career Academy is in.<ref name=":2" />
The school cost $24.5 million to construct.<ref name=":1" />
== Location == Vernon Malone College and Career Academy is located at 220 South Wilmington Street in Raleigh, North Carolina. The school is just south of highway [[Interstate 40|I-40]] and the [[Raleigh Beltline]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.google.com/maps?q=vernon+malone&oe=utf-8&client=firefox-b-1-ab&um=1&ie=UTF-8&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwif0f_hn__dAhVR3lMKHWWUAIcQ_AUIDygC|title=Google Maps|website=Google Maps|language=en|access-date=2018-10-11}}</ref>
== Students == Vernon Malone College and Career Academy operates on a modified-traditional calendar.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.wcpss.net/calendars|title=School Calendars / Overview|website=www.wcpss.net|language=en|access-date=2018-10-11}}</ref> Students begin school at 7:25 AM and end at 2:18 PM.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.wcpss.net/Page/1972|title=Vernon Malone College & Career Academy / Homepage|website=www.wcpss.net|language=en|access-date=2018-10-11}}</ref> They operate on a standard 2 Core 2 Electives [[Block scheduling|block schedule]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.wcpss.net/domain/1395|title=Calendars and Bell Schedules / Bell Schedules|website=www.wcpss.net|language=en|access-date=2018-10-11}}</ref>
In its first year, the school only had 131 students, which was only 28% of its capacity.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.newsobserver.com/article10065629.html|title=Wake County school board members say low enrollment at CTE high school was ‘predictable’|work=newsobserver|access-date=2018-10-11|language=en}}</ref> In 2016, the school had a total 306 students, with a student-to-teacher ratio of 16.1.<ref name=":3">{{Cite web|url=https://www.schooldigger.com/go/NC/schools/0472003345/school.aspx|title=Vernon Malone College and Career Academy|website=SchoolDigger|language=en|access-date=2018-10-11}}</ref> 42.5% of students in 2016 received [[School meal|free or reduced lunch]].<ref name=":3" />
== Academics == [[File:VMCCA9.png|thumb|261x261px|Vernon Malone College and Career Academy in 2018.]] Vernon Malone College and Career Academy offers 4 [[English literature|English]] literature courses, 7 [[Mathematics]] courses, 5 [[Science]] courses, 5 [[Social studies|Social Studies]] history courses, 6 [[Foreign language|Foreign Language]] courses, 5 [[Physical education|Physical Education]] (PE) courses, 4 [[Art]] courses, and 12 [[Vocational education|Career and Technical Education]] (CTE) courses, not including any of the Wake Technical Community College courses. Of those courses, 3 are [[Advanced Placement]] (AP).<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.wcpss.net/domain/13902|title=Course Description Guide / Overview|website=www.wcpss.net|language=en|access-date=2018-10-11}}</ref> These courses are accompanied by the 7 [[College|college programs]], offered by Wake Technical Community College. Students are able to receive college credits that can be applied towards an [[Associate degree]], diploma, or certificate at Wake Tech.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.waketech.edu/about-wake-tech/locations/vernon-malone|title=Vernon Malone College & Career Academy {{!}} Wake Technical Community College|website=www.waketech.edu|language=en|access-date=2018-10-11}}</ref>
The school also offers various fifth-period courses after school for juniors and seniors.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.wcpss.net/site/default.aspx?PageType=3&DomainID=2863&ModuleInstanceID=12073&ViewID=6446EE88-D30C-497E-9316-3F8874B3E108&RenderLoc=0&FlexDataID=118092&PageID=5594|title=News - Detail Page|website=www.wcpss.net|language=en|access-date=2018-10-11}}</ref>
== Sports == Athletics programs are not offered at Vernon Malone College and Career Academy. Students are eligible to participate in athletics at Southeast Raleigh Magnet High School.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.wcpss.net/domain/2715|title=Athletics / Athletic Information|website=www.wcpss.net|language=en|access-date=2018-10-11}}</ref>
== Clubs & Organizations == Vernon Malone College and Career Academy has 13 official clubs/organizations as of the 2018-2019 school year<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.wcpss.net/site/Default.aspx?PageID=2493|title=Activities / Homepage|website=www.wcpss.net|language=en|access-date=2018-10-11}}</ref>
* [[Video game|Gaming Club]] * [[Key Club]] * [[National Achievers Society]] * [[Programming language|Programming Club]] * [[Public speaking|Public Speaking & Debate Club]] * [[Robotics|Robotics Club]] * [[Violence|Students Against Violence Everywhere (SAVE)]] * [[SkillsUSA]] * [[Students' union|Student Government]] * [[Democratic Party (United States)|Teen Democrats]] * [[Drama|The Academy]] * [[Yearbook|Yearbook Club]]
== Threats == A student was arrested in February 2018 for threatening to 'shoot up' Vernon Malone College and Career Academy during a FaceTime conversation.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.cbs17.com/news/local-news/knightdale-teen-charged-with-threatening-to-shoot-up-school-showing-gun-on-facetime_20180313070545361/1036262065|title=Knightdale teen charged with threatening to 'shoot up' school, showing gun on FaceTime|last=Zarcone|first=Patrick|date=2018-02-22|work=WNCN|access-date=2018-10-11|language=en-US}}</ref> The school responded by increasing security at the school.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.newsobserver.com/news/local/crime/article201519549.html|title=Wake teen charged with threat to ‘shoot up’ career academy in Raleigh|work=newsobserver|access-date=2018-10-11|language=en}}</ref>
== Flooding == During Hurricane Matthew, the Raleigh area sustained heavy rainfall which flooded Vernon Malone College and Career Academy and displaced students for a few months while repairs were made.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.newsobserver.com/news/weather/article146581849.html|title=Vernon Malone school closes early because of flooding; other schools on regular schedule|work=newsobserver|access-date=2018-10-11|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.newsobserver.com/news/local/education/wake-ed-blog/article107735152.html|title=Flooded Vernon Malone Academy recovers from Hurricane Matthew|work=newsobserver|access-date=2018-10-11|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://abc11.com/weather/wake-county-school-sustains-terrible-flood-damage/1551889/|title=Wake County school sustains terrible flood damage|last=|first=|date=2016-10-12|work=ABC11 Raleigh-Durham|access-date=2018-10-11|language=en-US}}</ref>
== Awards == In 2018, Vernon Malone College and Career Academy received the ''[[Magnet Schools of America|Magnet School of Distinction Award]]'' for meeting all basic requirements outlined in the merit awards scoring rubric.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://magnet.edu/awards#merit-awards|title=Magnet Schools of America|last=America|first=Magnet Schools of|website=magnet.edu|access-date=2018-10-11}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.wcpss.net/vernonmalonecca|title=Vernon Malone College & Career Academy / Homepage|website=www.wcpss.net|language=en|access-date=2018-10-11}}</ref>

'''Website localization''' is the process of adapting an existing website to local language and culture in the [[target market]].<ref name="Payne">{{cite web|url=http://www.webpronews.com/topnews/2004/10/08/culture-and-website-localization|title=Culture and Website Localization|last=Payne|first=Neil|date=8 October 2004|work=[[WebProNews]]|accessdate=29 November 2010|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5uaaxzK3s|archivedate=29 November 2010}}</ref> It is the process of adapting a website into a different linguistic and cultural context<ref name=SANDRINI>{{cite journal|last=Sandrini|first=Peter|title=Website Localization and Translation|journal=MuTra 2005 – Challenges of Multidimensional Translation: Conference Proceedings|series=EU-High-Level Scientific Conference Series|issue=131-138|url=http://www.translationconcepts.org/pdf/MuTra_2005_Proceedings.pdf#page=135|accessdate=26 February 2014}}</ref>— involving much more than the simple translation of text. This modification process must reflect specific language and cultural preferences in the content, images and overall design and requirements of the site – all while maintaining the integrity of the website. Culturally adapted web sites reduce the amount of required cognitive efforts from visitors of the site to process information, making navigation easier and attitudes toward the web site more favorable.<ref name="Shneor">{{cite journal|last=Shneor|first=Rotem|date=2014-02-28|title=Influences of culture, geography, and infrastructure on website localization|url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/1034102170?accountid=14667|journal=Cross Cultural Management|volume=19|issue=3|pages=352–374|access-date=2017-12-06|via=}}</ref> The modification of the website must additionally take into consideration the stated purpose of the new website with a focus on the targeted audience/market in the new locale.<ref name=SANDRINI/> Website localization aims to customize a website so that it seems "natural", to its viewers despite cultural differences between the creators and the audience.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Shneor|first=Rodem|title=Influences of culture, geography and infrastructure on website localization decisions|journal=Cross Cultural Management: An International Journal|date=2012|volume=19|issue=3|pages=352–374|url=http://www.emeraldinsight.com/journals.htm?articleid=17047475|accessdate=19 March 2014|doi=10.1108/13527601211247099}}</ref> Two factors are involved—programming expertise and linguistic/cultural knowledge.<ref name="Payne"/>
The proliferation of website localization is the result of the popularity of computer and Internet users. People all over the world treat the Internet as their main location for information and services. These people do not all speak the same language. As a result, website localization has become one of the primary tools for business global expansion.<ref>{{cite web|title=Website Localization|url=https://asianabsolute.co.uk/website-localization|publisher=Asian Absolute|accessdate=25 May 2016}}</ref>
Due to website communication across multiple cultures for multiple needs, the Internet has given way to non professional translation practices. Because website localization involves mixed strategies, organizations tend to maintain a global image while using website localization to appeal to local users.<ref name="Pym">{{cite web|url= http://www.oxfordhandbooks.com/view/10.1093/oxfordhb/9780199239306.001.0001/oxfordhb-9780199239306-e-028|title = Oxford Handbooks|last=Pym|first=Anthony|date=26 February 2014}}</ref> The challenge of website localization has become even more important as websites increasingly have the potential to both supplement and replace presence in foreign markets. As web design becomes more congruent with national culture, it will foster online consumer purchasing.<ref name="Shneor"/> Creators take into account the "language, education level, belief and value systems, [and] traditions and habits" of the target culture in order to optimize results.<ref name=Shneor />
==Process== Website localization is more than mere [[translation]].<ref name="Tan">{{cite news|url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2001-08-06/business/0108060190_1_localization-translation-web-sites|title=Translators go beyond language as Web sites cross borders|last=Tan|first=Shannon|date=6 August 2001|work=[[The Miami Herald]]|accessdate=29 November 2010|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5uabN4muG|archivedate=29 November 2010}}</ref> Translating only solves partial language problems. Measurement units must be converted; images and text are modified to appeal to the target culture.<ref name="Tan"/>
The process of website localization is complex and involves three different levels of adaptation.<ref>{{cite web|title=What is Localization?|url=http://www.gx-localizations.com/about.asp|publisher=GX Localizations|accessdate=26 February 2014}}</ref> First is translation. Website localization involves adapting any text being used into the language of the country. It is important that translation of information be “clear and understandable” to avoid cultural misunderstanding or offense.<ref name=SANDRINI /> In order to translate, the "target culture" must be known.<ref name="Stanley 1999 127–129">{{cite book|last=Stanley|first=John|title=SIGDOC '99 Proceedings of the 17th annual international conference on Computer documentation|year=1999|publisher=ACM|location=New York, NY|isbn=1-58113-072-4|pages=127–129|url=http://delivery.acm.org/10.1145/320000/318569/p127-stanley.pdf?ip=141.213.236.110&id=318569&acc=ACTIVE%20SERVICE&key=B5D9E165A72B697C%2E0A17827594E6F2C8%2E4D4702B0C3E38B35%2E4D4702B0C3E38B35&CFID=419590667&CFTOKEN=40207095&__acm__=1394480330_f23b71ce60f010c26de5d84eebbfbb5b}}</ref> Second is the actual localization, which includes translation but also involves all other efforts and activities to ensure that the adaptation of textual materials, visual displays, illustrations and graphics are “linguistically and culturally appropriate for the target locale.” <ref name=SANDRINI /> Target locale is understood as the “[[Market segmentation|market segment]] defined by criteria including language, currency, and perhaps educational level or income bracket.” <ref name=PYM>{{cite journal|last=Pym|first=Anthony|title=Website localization|year=2011|url=http://usuaris.tinet.cat/apym/on-line/translation/2009_website_localization.pdf}}</ref> Among the many technical elements which can be localized are: date and time formats, currency formats, number formats, address and telephone number formats, units of measure and connection speed.<ref name=PYM /> In order to ensure effective communication during the localization process, it is important to consider the following items: [[information architecture]], theme and navigation, [[graphics]], photographs, audio, and visual.<ref name="Stanley 1999 127–129"/> Third is [[Internationalization and localization|internationalization]], which involves making sure that the software being used is fully compatible with the technology of the country in question.
There are two important considerations to keep in mind during the process of website localization. The first is to focus on the demands of the user.<ref name=SANDRINI /> The readers of the “localized version of the website” want to be able to read and understand the pages in a way that makes sense to them.<ref name=SANDRINI /> A second consideration is to take into account the goals of the client, whether an institution, government or individual, for example.<ref name=SANDRINI />
==Backend localization== Many elements of a website that are different according to the locale of the client need only minor manual changes by a localizer, or none at all. For example, the system on which the website is created should automatically produce the correct currency symbol based on the country in which the client is located.<ref name=LAKO>{{cite web|last=Lako|first=Cristian|title=The Elements of the Website Localizations Process|url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/1321921734/abstract?accountid=14667|work=Studia Universitatis Petru Major. Philogia|publisher=Universitatea Petru Maior|accessdate=28 February 2014}}</ref> * Website Analytics Software:<ref name=LAKO /> This software can be created once generally, and then applied to each of the localized domains. * Site Search: Results can be reviewed using an algorithm that sifts through possible results using [[metadata]]. For example, a consumer who makes a query in the United States should not be shown a good that can only be purchased in Portugal.<ref name=LAKO /> * Testimonials: Comments and feedback are often a vital part of a website. Localization efforts usually only include censorship. This can be done largely by software, however human review is sometimes necessary.<ref name=LAKO /> * Information Storage: [[Databases]] are often used to store large amounts of information. They can be used to store generic data, like product information, as well as more specific information pertaining to certain locales.<ref name=LAKO />
==The business of website localization== Using website localization to its best advantage is vital to any business seeking to move into international markets. With more and more companies seeking to tap into these lucrative markets, website localization has become quite profitable.<ref name=SANDRINI /> The business side involves global and local coordination; production and operations, including finance; sales and marketing; language translation, including technology and linguistic coordination; software engineering, as well as design.<ref name=PYM /><ref>{{cite web|last=Wandrianne|first=Dias|title=The Business Behind Translation|url=http://www.ccaps.net/blog/the-business-behind-translation/|accessdate=26 February 2014}}</ref> The higher the technological abilities of the target culture, the more likely it is for website localization to be implemented and used effectively.<ref name=Shneor />
==See also== *[[Internationalization and localization]] *[[Language localisation]]

[[File:Roman Catholic Elementary School- Life at St Joseph's, Upper Norwood, 1943 D14456.jpg |thumb|right|200px|A music teacher leading a music ensemble in an elementary school in 1943]] '''Women in music education''' describes the role of [[Women in music|women musicians, conductors, teachers and educational administrators]] in [[music education]] at the [[elementary school]] and [[secondary education]] levels. While [[music critic]]s argued in the 1880s that "...women lacked the innate creativity to compose good music" due to "biological predisposition",<ref name="parlorsongs.com">{{cite web|url=http://parlorsongs.com/issues/2002-9/thismonth/feature.php |title=Women Composers In American Popular Song, Page 1 |publisher=Parlorsongs.com |date=1911-03-25 |accessdate=2016-01-20}}</ref> later, it was accepted that women would have a role in [[music education]], and they became involved in this field "...to such a degree that women dominated music education during the later half of the 19th century and well into the 20th century."<ref name="parlorsongs.com"/> "Traditional accounts of the history of music education [in the US] have often neglected the contributions of women, because these texts have emphasized bands and the top leaders in hierarchical music organizations." <ref name="Sandra Wieland Howe 2015">Dr. Sandra Wieland Howe. "Women Music Educators In The United States: A History", in ''GEMS (Gender, Education, Music, and Society)'', the on-line journal of Gender Research in Music Education. Vol 8, No 4 (2015)</ref> When looking beyond these bandleaders and top leaders, women had many music education roles in the "...home, community, churches, public schools, and teacher-training institutions" and "...as writers, patrons, and through their volunteer work in organizations."<ref name="Sandra Wieland Howe 2015"/>
Despite the limitations imposed on women's roles in music education in the 19th century, women were accepted as [[kindergarten]] teachers, because this was deemed to be a "private sphere". Women also taught music privately, in girl's schools, Sunday schools, and they trained musicians in school music programs. By the turn of the 20th century, women began to be employed as music supervisors in elementary schools, teachers in [[normal school]]s and professors of music in universities. Women also became more active in professional organizations in music education, and women presented papers at conferences.
A woman, Frances Clarke (1860–1958) founded the [[National Association for Music Education|Music Supervisors National Conference]] in 1907. While a small number of women served as President of the Music Supervisors National Conference (and the following renamed versions of the organization over the next century) in the early 20th century, there were only two female Presidents between 1952 and 1992, which "[p]ossibly reflects discrimination." After 1990, however, leadership roles for women in the organization opened up. From 1990 to 2010, there were five female Presidents of this organization.<ref name="slideshare.net">{{cite web|url=http://www.slideshare.net/bigbadbariguru/a-historical-view-of-women-in-music-education-careers |title=A historical view of women in music education careers |publisher=Slideshare.net |date=2012-07-05 |accessdate=2016-01-20}}</ref> Women music educators "outnumber men two-to-one" in teaching general music, choir, private lessons, and keyboard instruction.<ref name="slideshare.net"/> More men tend to be hired as for band education, administration and jazz jobs, and more men work in colleges and universities.<ref name="slideshare.net"/> According to Dr. Sandra Wieland Howe, there is still a "[[glass ceiling]]" for women in music education careers, as there is "stigma" associated with women in leadership positions and "men outnumber women as administrators."<ref name="slideshare.net"/>
==Notable individuals== *[[Julia Crane]] (1855–1923) (1855–1923) was an [[music education in the United States|American music educator]] who set up a school, the [[Crane School of Music]] in [[Potsdam (town), New York|Potsdam, New York]], which was the first school specifically for the training of public school music teachers.<ref>Campbell and Klinger, pg. 276</ref> She is among the most important figures in the history of American music education.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://post.queensu.ca/~grime/v3n1.html|accessdate=May 19, 2008|title=Women in American Music Education: How Names Mentioned in History Books are Regarded by Contemporary Scholars|work=MENC Sessions (April 1994)|author=Carolyn Livingston}}</ref> Crane was a student of [[Manuel García (baritone)|Manuel García]].<ref>"Garcia's Method of Breathing", Werner's Magazine, December 1889, 270.</ref> Crane was inducted into the Music Educators Hall of Fame in 1986.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.menc.org/information/histinfo/Historicalinfohall.html|title=Music Educators Hall of Fame Honorees|accessdate=May 19, 2008|publisher=Music Educators Hall of Fame}}</ref> As of 2015, the Crane School of Music is one of three schools which make up the [[State University of New York at Potsdam|State University of New York (SUNY) at Potsdam]]. It has 630 undergraduate and 30 graduate students and a faculty of 70 teachers and professional staff. *Frances Clarke (1860–1958) was a music supervisor in the Milwaukee Public School system. She founded the [[National Association for Music Education|Music Supervisors National Conference]] in 1907. It was an organization of American music educators dedicated to advancing and preserving music education as part of the core curriculum of schools in the [[United States]]. In 2011, it was renamed the National Association for Music Education and it had more than 130,000 members.<ref>{{cite web|title= Press Reslease: Building on the Past to Shape the Future of Music Education|url=http://www.nafme.org/news/view/press-release-building-on-the-past-to-shape-the-future-of-music-education/|year=2011|work=NAfME official website|publisher=NAfME|accessdate=11 September 2011}}</ref> and in March 2012, Professor Glenn Nierman was elected President-Elect of NAfME.<ref>{{cite web|title= New NAfME President Seeks to Restore Trust|url=http://sociomusicology.blogspot.com/2012/03/new-nafme-president-seeks-to-restore.html|year=2012|work=Sociomusicology blog|publisher=David Hebert|accessdate=13 March 2012}}</ref> *Elsie Shaw (1866–1962) was a music supervisor in St. Paul, Minnesota. She supervised and taught elementary school teachers and conducted choirs and orchestras. She encouraged the offering of music education at the high school level.<ref name="slideshare.net"/> *[[Satis N. Coleman|Satis Coleman]] (1878–1961), who taught at Teachers College, Columbia University and Lincoln Lab School in the 1920s and 30s, created a popular method for teaching music creatively.<ref>{{cite journal | doi = 10.1017/S0265051700007622 | volume=7 | title=A Music Education Pioneer – Dr Satis Naronna Barton Coleman | journal=British Journal of Music Education | page=123}}</ref> She published many books that were foundational to music education, ethnomusicology, and out-of-school music scholarship.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://elibrary.ru/item.asp?id=5743978|title=SATIS N. COLEMAN (1878-1961): HER CAREER IN MUSIC EDUCATION|website=Elibrary.ru|accessdate=15 August 2018}}</ref> Her pedagogy involved field trips, instrument construction (often of non-Western instruments), and improvisation, and her philosophy had spiritual and ecological aspects.<ref>{{cite journal | doi = 10.1177/0027432115590182 | volume=102 | title=Satis Coleman—A Spiritual Philosophy for Music Education | journal=Music Educators Journal | pages=56–61}}</ref> *Mabelle Glenn (1881-1969) was a music supervisor in Bloomington, Indiana and a director of music in Kansas City, Missouri. She wrote [[music appreciation]] books and music textbooks. She was President of the [[National Association for Music Education|Music Supervisors National Conference]] from 1928–1930.<ref name="slideshare.net"/> *Lilla Pitts (1884–1970) graduated from [[Northwestern University]]. She was a faculty member of the teacher's college at [[Florida State University]]. She served as President of the [[National Association for Music Education|Music Educators National Conference]] (the new name for the Music Supervisors National Conference) from 1942–1944.<ref name="slideshare.net"/> *Marguerite Hood (1903–1992) graduated from the [[University of Southern California]]. She was a supervisor of music for Montana, a faculty member at the [[University of Montana]], the [[University of Southern California]] and the [[University of Michigan]]. She was President of the Music Educators National Conference from 1950–1952. She was the first woman to be appointed as chair of the ''[[Music Educators Journal]]''.<ref name="slideshare.net"/> *Frances Andrews (1908–1976) received her Masters and Doctorate from [[Pennsylvania State University]], where she was a faculty member from 1943 to 1973. She was President of the Music Educators National Conference from 1970–1972.<ref name="slideshare.net"/> *Mary Hoffman (1926–1997) graduated with a bachelor's degree in science from [[Lebanon Valley College]] and a Masters from [[Columbia Teachers College]]. She was a music supervisor in Milwaukee and Philadelphia. She gave graduate courses at Columbia Teachers College, [[Temple University]] and the [[University of Illinois]]. She wrote and contributed to textbooks. She was President of the Music Educators National Conference from 1980–1982.<ref name="slideshare.net"/> *Dorothy Straub (born 1941) graduated with Bachelors and master's degrees in music education from [[Indiana University]]. She was the music coordinator for Fairfield Public Schools in Connecticut. She was a violinist in two orchestras. She was given awards from the [[American String Teachers Association|ASTA]] and the National School Orchestra Association. She was President of the Music Educators National Conference from 1992–1994.<ref name="slideshare.net"/> *Carolynn Lindeman (born 1940) graduated from [[Oberlin College Conservatory of Music]], the Mozarteum Academy, [[San Francisco State University]] and [[Stanford University]], where she received her [[Doctor of Musical Arts]]. She was a professor at San Francisco State University from 1973 to 2005. She was President of the Music Educators National Conference from 1996–1998. She edited the "Strategies for Teaching" series. She "[a]cknoledge[d] discrimination in academia."<ref name="slideshare.net"/> *June Hinckley (1943–2007) graduated with a PhD from [[Florida State University]]. She was a music and fine arts supervisor in Brevard County in Florida. She wrote articles on music education. She was President of the Music Educators National Conference from 1998–2000.<ref name="slideshare.net"/> *Lynn Brinckmeyer received her PhD from the [[University of Kansas]]. She was an Associate Professor and Director of Choral Music Education at [[Texas State University]]. She was President of the Music Educators National Conference from 2006–2008.<ref name="slideshare.net"/> *Barbara Geer graduated from the [[University of North Carolina]]. She was a music consultant for a school system in North Carolina. She was President of the Music Educators National Conference from 2008–2010.<ref name="slideshare.net"/>
